document.text: Womens Missionary Society of liberty Baptist Church The Women Missionary Society of Liberty Baptist Church, or rather known first as the Ladie  Aid Society, was organized by Rev. Dr Henry W. Tribble in the year of his pastorate of this church, in 18 85. It was a small and feeble beginning but an earnest Christian spirit and effort tup ported the movement of this struggling band of Christian workers. Dr. Tribble even in vited the men to join the society so as to encourage and help the ladies in their Christian work Miss Sue Sears was elected president for several years, and she was active and efficient in the society, as in all other church work, wherever her consecrated life found work for the Heavenly Father Miss Sears best endeavors for His cause were always given I remember a few of the orig inal members Mrs. William H Gills, Mrs. William H. Abbitt Mrs. Joel Oawthorn, Mrs. T. A Caldwell, Mrs. C. W. Hancock Misses Sis OConner, Sis Ab bitt, and Lula Jones. This society met in the Amen corn er of the chnrch for years, after the regular monthly service on the 3rd Sunday of each month This society did much church work in individual ways, but rarely ever had any money, ex cept a few cents in the treasury. We tried lawn parties, lectures, oyster suppers, tableaux, etc. But rains, illness, or something seemed to break us up, minus of finances. If we raised fire or ten dollars a year for our society we thought we had done well, aa in those days ladies Ad minis- were not supposed to have any

Copenhaver, of Rich mond and Appomattox were hos tesses at dinner in honor of Miss Eloise Gills and William Ray Saville whose marriage will be an event of November. Mrs. Gills is the grand mother and Mrs. Copenhaver is an aunt of the bride-elect. An arrange ment of white flowers formed the centerpiece. The honoree was pre sented a gift. Others present includ ed Mrs. R. E. Saville, Mr. and Mrs. Van T. Wood, Mr. and Mrs. J. Allen Gills, Mrs. Rebecca Shanks, Bobby Saville, Miss Joan Gills and Hugh Spencer.

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: Hixburg. Rev. S. H . Thompson, of South Boston, aided Rev. P. T. Warren in a meeting at Walkers Church last week. Mr. Thompson is a conse crated Christian, and preaches with earnestness and power. Only four persons made a public profession of religion, but the Christians feel that they have been benefited and encour aged by the sermons of the week, and will always remember Brother Thompson in their homes, especial ly around their family altars. During sthe meeting there were several visitors in Hixburg neigh borhood  Miss Gold, of Richmond  Misses Ellen Cunningham and Kale Verser, of Earmville and Misses Elcan and Jones, of Buckingham. document.text: On May 16, Troop 46 of the Boy Scouts attended the morning service at Memorial Methodist Church. They were accompanied by their Scout master, Eames A. Powers. The troop in Appomattox is sponsored by the Lions Club. Scoutmaster Powers states that he hopes to make periodic attendance at alternate churches a regular part of the Scout program. Those attending the service Sun day were Richard E. Hamilton, 2nd class Scout and Senior Patrol Lead er John S. Evans, Tenderfoot, As sistant Patrol Leader William H. Caldwell, Tenderfoot, Assitant Pa trol Leader Brian E. Thomas, Ten derfoot, Patrol Leader Thomas E. Holland, Tenderfoot, Scribe Julian C. Gills, Tenderfott, Stephen W. Runkle, Tenderfott, Patrol Leader Samuel E. Shouse, Jr., Tenderfoot Holcombe T. Wood, Tenderfoot Charles F. P. Crawley, Jr., Tender foot Franklin L. Burke. Those not attendeding, but members of the troop Kenneth Lovell, Daniel C. Paulette, Wilson K. Fleshman, Walter E. Hancock, Clyde F. Mitchell, Wil bur C. Fleshman, William Runkle, Life Scout and Junior Assistant Scoutmaster. Summer activities of the troop will include overnight camping trips, a party and attendance at the Scout Camp Monocan.

document.text: A wedding of widespread interest gas solemnized Tuesday evening at .30 in Liberty Baptist Churci here, when Miss Josephine aullivar. .Jenkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Spurgeon Jenkin?, became He bride of Captain Jack Marvin Dickerson, United States Army Air Corps, son of Mr. and Mvs James y, Dickerson, of Kenbridge, Vir ginia. The brides pastor, the Rev. Frederick Jones, was the offi- sting minister, the ring ceremony hi ng used. The church was deco- fsted wi h cathedral candles, palms and white flowers. Ah organ prelude was rendjred by Miss Cornelia Ky.e Gills  Ain hfan Aimee,  My Hart at. Thy Mveet Voice,  Ve.ietian Love Jong,  Barcarolle Se-er-lae and Mr. John Curtis Caldwml sang  Be cause and  At Dawning.  i The bride, who was given in mar- fiage by her father, wore a wed ding gown of ivory slipper satin fanioned with high round neck iealloped yoke of marquisette, long sleeves tapered to points over the bands shirred panel .basque bodice with the fullness of the gathered gkirt forming a sweeping train.Her full length veil of imported illusion dotted with buds or orange blos som s fell from a bandeau of orange blossoms. document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

Dr. Brumfield, district health officer in co-operation with county physicians will begin week of May 26th to examine ail children of Appomatto couhty who expect to Tbegir school next session. Parents will get in touch with their family physician and make ar rangements to have children examined The cost will be slight to each Each physician has set aside one day during the week begining the 26th for these examinations at his office. William- Pitzer Gills after 27 years as carrier on Route 2 retired yesterday in good health. He had gotten several extensions and his last one ex pired yesterday and he is in town to-day receiving the con gratulations of his friends. The post office employees pre sented Mr. Gills with a new hat just the kind he likes, and the presentation and acceptance speeches were mingled with Motto Wool- tears. Just what Pitzer will T h e l m a  dno one knows but it-- 181 hoped that as he works the flowers garden at home the fragrance and beauty of his home will give him a life of joy and pleasure. Mr. Gills is 71 years of age.

Hoge Tyler, of Rad ford, former Governor of Virginia, was operated on here at the Jeffer son Hospital. He stood the opera tion well, in spite of his 66 years. Governor Tyler was accompanied here by several members of his fam ily. His condition is serious and the physicians say it. is too early to say whether he will survive the ef fects of the operation. Fredericksburg.The Daughters of the Confederacy, of this city, have conferred crosses of honor on B. F. Price, A. A. Cannady, A. D. Jett and L. A. Weaver, Confederate veterans, and W. Key Howard, son of a vet eran. The chapter elected Miss Etta Barney and Mrs. G. R. Swift dele gates to the annual convention of the United Daughters of the Con federacy, which convenes in Roa noke. Lynchburg. A new lodge of Re- bekahs has been formed at Fairview Heights, to be known as Oak Leaf Lodge, No. 15. The officers are Noble grand, Mrs. J. W. Gills vice grand, Mrs. B. H. Goding, recording secretary, Miss Hattie Patterson ebr- responding secretary, Miss Pearl Bu- comb treasurer, Miss Arrah Fergu son warden, Miss Edna Ferguson conductor, Mrs. H. F. Watts inside guardian, Mrs. R. W. Callahan, ana chaplain, Miss Edna Callahan. Fredericksburg.The street com mittee of the fcity Council has award ed J. H. Davis the contract for ma cadamizing the roadway on the west side of Washington avenue and the circles at Mercer Monument. The contract price is 1,200. Newport News. Judge Beverly Randolph Wellford, aged 83 years, who for 40 years served as judge of the Circuit Court at Richmond, and who had been prominent in the Masonic affairs of the State, died at the home of his son here. Fredericksburg. The Wright-La- tane Camp of Confederate Veterans of Essex County has elected John M. Lewis, Dr. Warner Lewis, R. B. Whitlock, William Campbell, J. W. Phillips and Muscoe Garnett, Jr., delegates to the Grand Camp of Con federate Veterans, which convenes at Newport News October 17. Fredericksburg.  Rev. A. Jy Reamy and his son, who Is also a minister, have accepted calls to Fair- port, Fairfield, Smithfleld and Coan Baptist churches, in the Northern Neck. Harrisonburg.In the woods near Burketown Charles Ragner shot at a squirrel in a tree. The shot missed the squirrel and struck the breast and arms of Joseph Shaffer, who was in the tree gathering wild grapes. Neither man knew the other was In the woods. Shaffer is badly hurt, but will recover. Leesburg.The residence belong ing to Dr. John Cline, near Bluemont, was totally destroyed by fire Thurs day night. The origin is unknown. The loss was about 5.000. T. C. HsllM fir, deputy sheriff, and his .mil were occupying the house.

Blackwell, died at her home yesterday afternoon The deceased was formerly Miss Godsey, of Appomattox County. Sam Thornton of Graham was the guest of his sister, Mrs B- T. Gunter, of Evergreen, last week. Miss Bessie Thornhill of Lynchburg is a guest of Miss Fannie Clement. Lightning struck an old oak tree about forty years old in the yard of Mrs. Hubbard Mar tin and tore it to pieces last Friday evening. document.text: F our M asked Men E n te r th e House of P leasant H endricks N ear Lynchburg, K nock H im In!the H ead and Set F ire to th e House. On Deo. 51st., on the Lynchburg and Durham railroad, about six miles from Lynqhburg, a terrible crime was committed. Some- three weeks prior to the tragedy, the young and attractive daughter of Mr. J. H. White, of Lynchburg, was married to Pleasant Hendricks, of Campbell co.unty. They made their home near Bocock Station shortly afterward, and livedhappily together. On the night of Dep. 21st. between 9 and 10 oclook, Mrs. Hendricks was sitting in her room reading The Chil dren of the Abbeyand Mr.Hendrioks was asleep. There was bnt little flip on the hearth. The door was bolted with an ordinary lock bolt. All at once it was broken down and four masked men rushed into the room. One of them held an axe in bis hand, and rushing to the bed struck Hendricks on the head with the sharp edge. Mrs. Hendricks, over come by the right fainted, and when she became conscious was lying on a hastily improvised- pallet out in the yard, where she supposed she had been taken by the murderers. Thie house was enveloped iiyflames. Many of the neighbors were attracted by the light, but arrived too late to ex tinguish the Are or to rescue the body. er trunk had also been refnpved and was placed so near the burning building that it caught on fire and was entirely consumed. While the crowd stood about the burning house it was whispered around that four negroes from Jaok- son Town, a small suburb of Lynofar burg, bad been seen hunting in the neighborhood. Suspicion being arous ed, parties were immediately dis- latohed to arrest them. A ndthis was accomplished before morningi hree of the negroes were arrested by officers, and the fourth one sur rendered himself. In the meantime, when the flames died down, a search wB instituted tot the murdered man, and after a long hunt they found what was left of the body. The heart, lungs and a few fragments of bones were all that remained of what a few hours before bad been a prosperous,happy human beidg. Mr. Hendricks was an industrious and well-to-do farmer of about forty-five years of age, ahd was not known to have bad an enemy. On the day before, however, be had brought home 200, He had given bis wife 15 and placing the remain der in an oil cloth sack had con cealed it in the bed.. It is thought, that, as Mr. Hendricks had been hauling posts to Jackson Town while he had this money in his pos session, the negroes must have dis covered the fact and planned the robbery. On Dec. 23rd an inquisition was held at the scene of the crime, anc. was adjoqrned to the 27th to the Law Building at Lynchburg. Mr. W. M. Murrell, assisted by Mr. Thos. Whitehead, Jr., conducted the exam ination for tbe commonwealth, while the prisoners were represented by Maj. T. J. Kirkpatrick, Judge H. M. Ford and Mr. James W. Wright. The only witness called was Mrs. Hendricks. She identified the fonr negroes as the persons who entered her house, bnt her testimony die i not 6onvince the coroners jury for they were divided in their opinions as to the guilt of the men arrested who were Commodore Johnson, Rob ert Smith, William Coghill and William Fields. The coroner, Mr. John W. Gills, and three of the jnrors declared the deed to have been perpetrated by tbe prisoners, while the remaining three decided that the fatal blow had been struck by parties unknown. The  murder continues to be the all-absorbing topic of conversation among the county people. Many now believe that the four negroes are the guilty parties, while many others do not think that the right men have been captured and, from the latest reports, we learn that considerable indignation is expressed at the unnecessary detention of the prisoners. ________________ Toga Notes. document.text: gathering of the descendants of the late William Rosser. Mr. Rosser, a native of Fincastle, who had moved to Appomattox, was engaged in mak ing firearms in Richmond for the Confederacy during the War Be tween the States. At the close of hostilities he returned to Appomat tox. During the following years he had many and varied interests, in cluding a mercantile business, oper ating several farms, and serving as United States Postmaster for Appo mattox Court House. A buffet dinner was served in the house and on the lawn. The home was decorated with varigated sum mer flowers. All members of the family and guests registered on a large scroll provided for the occa sion. They wore white caps, with red decorations, on the front of which was inscribed, Rosser Clan. The surviving daughters of Mr. Rosser, Mrs. Clement A. Hancock of Huntington, West Va., and Mrs. Bessie Ferguson, of Roanoke and Appomattox, were crowned Queens for the day. The following descendants and out-of-town guests were present Mr. and Mrs. Guy Littleton Furr, Miss Mary Catherine Furr, Guy Littleton Furr, Jr., of Roanoke Judge Catherine Clement Dellinger. document.text: Thursday at noon at Libe tv Baptist Church here the marriage of Miss Lillie Neal Hancock to Mr. Abner H. Gregory was so len in Z d in tbe presence of a large audeuce. The church was decorated with cedar, chrysanthemums and carna tions and lighted with hundreds of candles. The bride met the groom under a large bell of flowers where her minister, Rev. George S. Ken- naid performed the ceremony in a very impressive manner. Miss Margaret Smith, teacher of music at the Union Acade uy oi Spout Springs, had jchaige of the music and played softly several se lections while the service was being performed. Mr. E. H. Matthew- 6on, who is at the headof the U. S. Experimental Station here, sang very sweetly Loves Old Sweet Song. Mrs. Frank Sheard, of Lynch burg, was matron of honor, and wore pink dress with roses. Miss Maude Gregory, sister of the gr-.om was maid of honor, and wore white net over pink silk and carried white roses. Capt. Nathan C. Hancock, broth er of the bride was best man. The brides attendants were Miss Margurite Marshall with Harry Hancock Miss Emma Smith with Walter B. Ellett Miss Helen Gregory with H. W. McKinney Miss Bertha Caldwell with A. .V. Jones Miss Mattie Jones with R E. Caldwell Miss Mary-Hancock with Joe LeGrande Mrs. Bessie James with Leonard Gregoiy Miss Sallie Goff with V. L. Raby Miss Maty W. Caluweil with John Goff Mies Annie Elliott witn II. C. Steele Mies Kate Cheatham with C. W. Stewart Miss Ossie Agee with William Jones. The brides maids were dressed in .white and carried pink roses. Little Virginia and Annie cock were flower giris and white aud carried pink and carnations. Royal Hancock, Tunstall gun, James Stanley, Janies Gills, Robert Walton, Willie Walton, Ben jamin.Kennard and Braxton Han cock were ribbon boys. The boys wore white suits and held white and pink ribbon. The bride wore white net trimmed in real lace over whine taffeta, and Uer bridal veil was caught with a beautiful brooch set with  tails, a gift from tbe groom, and a diamond pin, an heirloom of the family. She carried in her hand a white ptajer- book. They boarded the wes bound train tor a tiip west and will be at home to their tneuds here after the ,2tn. The bride is the very attractive young daughter of Mr. C. W. Han cock, a popular contractor of Lynchburg aud this place, and is one of the prominent and Highly connected families of the .Kate. The gioom is a fine young man of sterling qualities, a son ot Mr. N. H. Giegory, of this place arid holds a position with the N.  W. Ry. Co where be is highly esteemed by his comrades and employers. The presents presented to tbe bride were of a very high order, among them a deed to tbe hand somer. t home in the county from the father of tbe bride. This home has just been completed here and e healed throughout with generators, lighted,by acetylene gas -iud con tains every modern convenience. Tbe presents number 125 all told, and the bride is extremely happy and appreciative ovarihe thought fulness of her frieuds. RECEPTION. On Wednesday evening the s a- cious and palatial home was opened to the bridal party and an elegant reception was teudered those pres-jent. ent Rev. Mrs. Kennard presided at the table and Mrs. J. R. Atwood at the punch bowl. Mesduins E. W. Taylor, C. A. Hancock and Miss

McGill and little daughter, Alice, of Colorado, are visiting at the h o m e of Mrs. McGills father, Mr- F. F. Burke- C. H o 11 ywoodMr. Dillard Morris visited his sister, Mrs. Shelton Ferguson, on Sunday last. , . . . HixburgOn Tuesday night ibout nine oclock, the ware house of William Daniel Hix and Company was burned with all of its contents. document.text: Mrs. H. C. Aimond is sick. Misses Phoebe and Isabelh OBrien entertained the Pamp lin faculty and friends at a din ner-bridge party Friday. Miss Bernice Leuhr has beer visiting here as a guest of Pro fessor W. T. Smith. Llittle Murriell Ferguson cel ebrated his sixth birthday Sun day.Mrs. W. E. Smith continue very sick, but can have visitors Miss Virginia Reynolds it home for the summer. J. L. Cates had an automo bile accident while in North Carolina last week. The car was completely wrecked, bul Mr. Cates escaped serious in jury. Mr. and Mrs. Dottridge Mar tin have moved into Mr. Har woods cottage on Richmond highway. Mr. and Mrs. T. W Ferguson are moving into their new home tl !s week. Mrs. Flippo of Leesburg, is visiting her parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Upton. Mr. and Mrs. Jim Stanley and family, of Richmond, spent Sunday with Mrs. J. H. Stan ley. K Mrs. Allen Carter, of Tower Hill, returned with her sister, Mrs. G. L. Furr to Bluefield, on a visit. Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Smith, of Charlottesville, spent the week-end with Mr. and Mrs. M. C. Smith. i Miss Virginia Smith, of Rich mond, spent a week of her va cation fwith home people here. Mrs. L. B. Plittman, of Rich mond, spent several days with her parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. Pitzer Gills, recently. Mr. Pitzer Gills is visiting his son, Henry P. Gills, of Marion for ten days.  Mrs. !E. LeiRoy Smith, who has been visiting her mother Mrs. Pace, o f Halifax, who is critically ill has returned home Miss Gladys Inge, of Phila delphia is home for her sum mer vacation. Miss Alice Harwood and A R. Harwood ,Jr., are home for the summer. Miss Annie Hancock, Ned and Miss Lillian Caldwell go to FYanklin Wednesday to bring Miss Corinne Hancock home for the summer. Adiield McCain spent Sunday with his sister, Mrs. Dotteridge Martin. Mrs. E. T. Price spent sever al days last week in the home of Mrs. Walter Scott. T. A. Walton received news today that Billy Walton, Jr, has broken his arm. Mrs. Ida Morris, of Vera is visiting Mrs. H. M. Welch. Mrs. Shipman, of Williams burg, is visiting her sisters Mrs. D. N. Twyman and Mrs M. Lawson. Mr. and Mrs. J. A. Burke Miss Eula Mae Burke, Mrs. J B. Abbitt and Miss Venue Odor of Norfolk, attended the grad uation exercises of Miss Vay Abbitt, at Farmville Tuesday Mr. and Mrs. Joe LeGrand attended the graduation exer cises at West Hampton, .Tues day, where their daughter, Lu cy, received her degree. Mr. and Mrs. R. L. Burke will go to Charlottesville this week to see their son, William, finish his law course at U. of Va. J. S. McKenzie, of Doleware, Ohio, is visiting hiis daughter, Mrs. Wiley Morris.

document.text: Mrs D. G. Trent is spending some time in Williamsburg, with her son-in-law and daughter, Mr, and Mrs. John Tabb. John D. Littell returned to his home in Pittsburgh, Penna., Tues day after spending the summer with his brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. J. Berkley Drinkard. Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Almond, John T. Hall, Mrs. Eppes Johnson and daughter, Sarah Jane, and Mrs. B. S. Stewart were week-end guests of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Compton, in Ohley, West Virginia. Miss Mary Louise Gills, who re cently underwent an operation at Johnston-Willis Hospital, has re covered sufficiently to return to her home at 218 South Blvd., Rich mond. Mrs. Joel W. Flood, president of the Alice Kyle District, Virginia Federation of Womens Clubs, at tended a meeting of the board of directors of the Virginia Federation at the Cavalier Hotel in Virginia Beach last week. Miss Edna Gregory, a student at the College of William and Mary, Was home for the week-end to at tend the George - Stanley wedding. Miss Gregory had as her house guest, Miss Elizabeth Hix, a senior at Westhmpton College. Mrs. Irvin C. Moses visited her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Garrett Jr. in Balti more for the week-end. Also Mrs. C. B. Page, son and daughter-in- law visited her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Kent Guth rie in Baltimore over the week-end. Mary Alice and Peggy Henry, daughters of Mr, and Mrs. Walter Henry have entered Longwood Col lege. Mary Alice, a junior, is study ing to be an elementary teacher, while Peggy is majoring in journal ism. Mrs. Alpha Higginbotham return ed home .Saturday, after spending several weeks in Norfolk with her daughter, Mrs. Robert A. Elliott. Mr. and Mrs. Elliott and daughter, Susann accompanied her home and spent the week-end. Mr. and Mrs. J. D. Childress, of Lynchburg, are announcing the birth of a son, J. D. Jr., born at the Virginia Baptist Hospital Oct. 6. Mrs. Childress will be remembered here as Miss Shirley Mitchell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Mitchell. William Childs Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howlette Burge Martin, of Spout Spring, has returned to Hampton-Sydney College, where he is a member of the junior class Hampden-Sydney is now in its 180th session. Mrs. M. T. Shipman and daugh ter, Mrs. Gardner Tyler Brooks, of Williamsburg spent the week-end with Mrs. Shipmans niece, Mrs. Watt H. Stanley. They were here for the George - Stanley wedding on Saturday evening. Miss Rosa Mae Wooldridge, Mists Laura McFadden and Mrs. Stanley C. Boyce, as members of the board of directors of the new Lynchburg General Hospital, motored to Lynch burg Monday afternoon, where they joined other directors in making a

document.text: Mr. and Mrs. J. C. Caldwell spent Friday night in Roanoke, where they attended a district Lions Club con vention and dance. They motored to Radford Saturday.
